dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, we've been looking at some really interesting stuff happening with Guild Education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, uh, we've been looking at some really interesting stuff happening with Guild Education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Guild, right? They're that Denver-based company that's all about, like, helping frontline workers get more education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Guild, right? They're that Denver-based company that's all about, like, helping frontline workers get more education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And their CEO, Rachel Carlson, she was just at the Forbes Women's Summit, talking about this really surprising trend.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And their C E O, Rachel Carlson, she was just at the Forbes Women's Summit, talking about this really surprising trend.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, what's that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, what's that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: She's saying that when companies actually *restrict* their frontline workforce, uh, especially when it comes to things like education, they become way less attractive places to work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: She's saying that when companies actually restrict their frontline workforce, uh, especially when it comes to things like education, they become way less attractive places to work.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes total sense, right? Like, who wants to work somewhere that doesn't invest in them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes total sense, right? Like, who wants to work somewhere that doesn't invest in them?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! And she's got the data: lower retention rates, lower recruitment, worse brand image... it's all there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! And she's got the data: lower retention rates, lower recruitment, worse brand image... it's all there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: So, you'd think companies would be, like, all over this. Investing in their people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you'd think companies would be, like, all over this. Investing in their people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: You would! But here's the kicker, B. Companies like Chipotle, Discover, even Walt Disney – they're actually *avoiding* offering these kinds of education programs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You would! But here's the kicker, B. Companies like Chipotle, Discover, even Walt Disney - they're actually avoiding offering these kinds of education programs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So why exactly are companies like Chipotle, Discover and Walt Disney lining up to offer nearly free education to employees?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, why? That seems so counterintuitive!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, why? That seems so counterintuitive!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Carlson explained it. She says nearly every CEO she works with, um, has mentioned "sending their employees back to jail" in their earnings calls.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Carlson explained it. She says nearly every C E O she works with, um, has mentioned "sending their employees back to jail" in their earnings calls.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: "Back to jail?" What does that even mean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: "Back to jail?" What does that even mean?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a metaphor for, like, the perceived financial hit. They see these programs as damaging their short-term profits, hurting recruitment and retention in the immediate aftermath.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a metaphor for, like, the perceived financial hit. They see these programs as damaging their short-term profits, hurting recruitment and retention in the immediate aftermath.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. So they're prioritizing, uh, quarterly numbers over long-term employee loyalty and skill development?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. So they're prioritizing, uh, quarterly numbers over long-term employee loyalty and skill development?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And MSNBC anchor Stephanie Ruhle actually chimed in, saying she's never heard an analyst ask about the *bad* a company is doing in this area. It's all about the good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And M S N B C anchor Stephanie Ruhle actually chimed in, saying she's never heard an analyst ask about the bad a company is doing in this area. It's all about the good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, [overlap] you know, that's a fair point. It's all about the upside.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, you know, that's a fair point. It's all about the upside.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: But Guild estimates there are 64 million low-income and white-collar workers who are going to need more education just to compete in an increasingly automated world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Guild estimates there are sixty four million low-income and white-collar workers who are going to need more education just to compete in an increasingly automated world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, like, makes companies that *do* invest, like Walmart with their Live Better U program where employees pay just a dollar a year, look incredibly smart in the long run.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, like, makes companies that do invest, like Walmart with their Live Better U program where employees pay just a dollar a year, look incredibly smart in the long run.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's a huge opportunity, but it seems some companies are just too focused on the immediate bottom line to see it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's a huge opportunity, but it seems some companies are just too focused on the immediate bottom line to see it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. It’s a pretty short-sighted view, don't you think?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. It's a pretty short-sighted view, don't you think?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's like they're shooting themselves in the foot for the sake of, uh, a good quarterly report.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's like they're shooting themselves in the foot for the sake of, uh, a good quarterly report.
